defs.docs: The globset crate provides cross platform single glob and glob set matching.

attributes.value: deny(missing_docs)

defs.name: Glob
defs.docs: Glob represents a successfully parsed shell glob pattern.

attributes.value: / Glob represents a successfully parsed shell glob pattern.
/ It cannot be used directly to match file paths, but it can be converted
/ to a regular expression string or a matcher.

defs.name: GlobBuilder
defs.docs: A builder for a pattern.

attributes.value: / A builder for a pattern.
/ This builder enables configuring the match semantics of a pattern. For
/ example, one can make matching case insensitive.
/ The lifetime `'a` refers to the lifetime of the pattern string.

defs.docs: Builds a new pattern with default options.

attributes.value: / Builds a new pattern with default options.

defs.docs: Returns a matcher for this pattern.

attributes.value: / Returns a matcher for this pattern.

defs.name: glob
defs.docs: Returns the original glob pattern used to build this pattern.

attributes.value: / Returns the original glob pattern used to build this pattern.

defs.name: regex
defs.docs: Returns the regular expression string for this glob.

attributes.value: / Returns the regular expression string for this glob.
/ Note that regular expressions for globs are intended to be matched on
/ arbitrary bytes (`&[u8]`) instead of Unicode strings (`&str`). In
/ particular, globs are frequently used on file paths, where there is no
/ general guarantee that file paths are themselves valid UTF-8. As a
/ result, callers will need to ensure that they are using a regex API
/ that can match on arbitrary bytes. For example, the
/ [`regex`](https://crates.io/regex)
/ crate's
/ [`Regex`](https://docs.rs/regex/*/regex/struct.Regex.html)
/ API is not suitable for this since it matches on `&str`, but its
/ [`bytes::Regex`](https://docs.rs/regex/*/regex/bytes/struct.Regex.html)
/ API is suitable for this.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new builder for the pattern given.

attributes.value: / Create a new builder for the pattern given.
/ The pattern is not compiled until `build` is called.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Parses and builds the pattern.

attributes.value: / Parses and builds the pattern.

defs.name: case_insensitive
defs.value: pub fn case_insensitive(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut GlobBuilder
defs.docs: Toggle whether the pattern matches case insensitively or not.

attributes.value: / Toggle whether the pattern matches case insensitively or not.
/ This is disabled by default.

defs.name: literal_separator
defs.value: pub fn literal_separator(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut GlobBuilder
defs.docs: Toggle whether a literal `/` is required to match a path separator.

attributes.value: / Toggle whether a literal `/` is required to match a path separator.
/ By default this is false: `*` and `?` will match `/`.

defs.name: backslash_escape
defs.value: pub fn backslash_escape(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut GlobBuilder
defs.docs:
When enabled, a back slash (`\`) may be used to escape
 special characters in a glob pattern. Additionally, this will
 prevent `\` from being interpreted as a path separator on all
 platforms.

attributes.value: / When enabled, a back slash (`\`) may be used to escape
/ special characters in a glob pattern. Additionally, this will
/ prevent `\` from being interpreted as a path separator on all
/ platforms.
/ This is enabled by default on platforms where `\` is not a
/ path separator and disabled by default on platforms where `\`
/ is a path separator.

defs.name: Error
defs.docs: Represents an error that can occur when parsing a glob pattern.

attributes.value: / Represents an error that can occur when parsing a glob pattern.

defs.name: InvalidRecursive
defs.docs: **DEPRECATED**.

attributes.value: / **DEPRECATED**.
/ This error used to occur for consistency with git's glob specification,
/ but the specification now accepts all uses of `**`. When `**` does not
/ appear adjacent to a path separator or at the beginning/end of a glob,
/ it is now treated as two consecutive `*` patterns. As such, this error
/ is no longer used.

defs.name: UnclosedClass
defs.docs: Occurs when a character class (e.g., `[abc]`) is not closed.

attributes.value: / Occurs when a character class (e.g., `[abc]`) is not closed.

defs.name: InvalidRange
defs.docs:
Occurs when a range in a character (e.g., `[a-z]`) is invalid. For
 example, if the range starts with a lexicographically larger character
 than it ends with.

attributes.value: / Occurs when a range in a character (e.g., `[a-z]`) is invalid. For
/ example, if the range starts with a lexicographically larger character
/ than it ends with.

defs.name: UnopenedAlternates
defs.docs: Occurs when a `}` is found without a matching `{`.

attributes.value: / Occurs when a `}` is found without a matching `{`.

defs.name: UnclosedAlternates
defs.docs: Occurs when a `{` is found without a matching `}`.

attributes.value: / Occurs when a `{` is found without a matching `}`.

defs.name: NestedAlternates
defs.docs:
Occurs when an alternating group is nested inside another alternating
 group, e.g., `{{a,b},{c,d}}`.

defs.name: __Nonexhaustive
defs.docs: Hints that destructuring should not be exhaustive.

attributes.value: / Hints that destructuring should not be exhaustive.
/ This enum may grow additional variants, so this makes sure clients
/ don't count on exhaustive matching. (Otherwise, adding a new variant
/ could break existing code.)

defs.name: ErrorKind
defs.value:
pub enum ErrorKind {
    InvalidRecursive,
    UnclosedClass,
    InvalidRange(char, char),
    UnopenedAlternates,
    UnclosedAlternates,
    NestedAlternates,
    DanglingEscape,
    Regex(String),
    __Nonexhaustive,
}
defs.docs: The kind of error that can occur when parsing a glob pattern.

attributes.value: / The kind of error that can occur when parsing a glob pattern.

defs.docs: Returns true if any glob in this set matches the path given.

attributes.value: / Returns true if any glob in this set matches the path given.
/ This takes a Candidate as input, which can be used to amortize the

defs.name: matches
defs.value: pub fn matches<P: AsRef<Path>>(&Self, P) -> Vec<usize>
defs.docs:
Returns the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the
 given path.

attributes.value: / Returns the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the
/ given path.

defs.name: matches_candidate
defs.docs:
Returns the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the
 given path.

attributes.value: / Returns the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the
/ given path.
/ This takes a Candidate as input, which can be used to amortize the
/ cost of preparing a path for matching.

defs.name: matches_into
defs.value: pub fn matches_into<P: AsRef<Path>>(&Self, P, &mut Vec<usize>)
defs.docs:
Adds the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the given
 path to the vec given.

attributes.value: / Adds the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the given
/ path to the vec given.
/ `into` is cleared before matching begins, and contains the set of
/ sequence numbers (in ascending order) after matching ends. If no globs
/ were matched, then `into` will be empty.

defs.name: matches_candidate_into
defs.docs:
Adds the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the given
 path to the vec given.

attributes.value: / Adds the sequence number of every glob pattern that matches the given
/ path to the vec given.
/ `into` is cleared before matching begins, and contains the set of
/ sequence numbers (in ascending order) after matching ends. If no globs
/ were matched, then `into` will be empty.
/ This takes a Candidate as input, which can be used to amortize the
/ cost of preparing a path for matching.

defs.name: GlobSetBuilder
defs.docs:
GlobSetBuilder builds a group of patterns that can be used to
 simultaneously match a file path.

attributes.value: / GlobSetBuilder builds a group of patterns that can be used to
/ simultaneously match a file path.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Create a new GlobSetBuilder. A GlobSetBuilder can be used to add new
 patterns. Once all patterns have been added, `build` should be called
 to produce a `GlobSet`, which can then be used for matching.

attributes.value: / Create a new GlobSetBuilder. A GlobSetBuilder can be used to add new
/ patterns. Once all patterns have been added, `build` should be called
/ to produce a `GlobSet`, which can then be used for matching.

defs.name: build
defs.docs: Builds a new matcher from all of the glob patterns added so far.

attributes.value: / Builds a new matcher from all of the glob patterns added so far.
/ Once a matcher is built, no new patterns can be added to it.

defs.docs: Add a new pattern to this set.

attributes.value: / Add a new pattern to this set.

defs.name: Candidate
defs.docs: A candidate path for matching.

attributes.value: / A candidate path for matching.
/ All glob matching in this crate operates on `Candidate` values.
/ Constructing candidates has a very small cost associated with it, so
/ callers may find it beneficial to amortize that cost when matching a single
/ path against multiple globs or sets of globs.

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub fn new<P: AsRef<Path> + ?Sized>(&'a P) -> Candidate
defs.docs: Create a new candidate for matching from the given path.

attributes.value: / Create a new candidate for matching from the given path.
